news.title: Cuban delegation tours Liberation City
news.content:
Blessings Chidakwa

Herald Reporter

The Cuban delegation, led by president of the National Assembly, Honourable Esteban Lazo Hernandez, has toured the Liberation City encompassing the Museum of African Liberation.

During the tour, Honourable Hernandez saw artefacts, studios and the structure of the Museum of African Liberation which is under construction.

He proceeded to water a Cuban tree that is adjacent their nations flag.

During the tour, Honourable Hernandez also donated a picture book of the late Cuban revolutionary leader, Fidel Castro, to the Museum of African Liberation.

Ambassador Kwame Muzavazi, CEO of the Institute of African Knowledge (INSTAK), also handed the Africa Fact Book to the Cuban delegation.

Among the delegates was the Minister of State for Harare Metropolitan Provincial Affairs and Devolution, Cde Charles Tawengwa, Zanu PFs Secretary for International Relations and Special Envoy of the President in his recent visit to Cuba, Cde

Simbarashe Mumbengegwi and Zanu PF deputy commissar, Cde Webster Shamu.
news.description: The Cuban delegation, led by president of the National Assembly, Honourable Esteban Lazo Hernandez, has toured the Liberation City encompassing the Museum of African Liberation.

news.title: Lake Kariba poised to transform Zim’s blue economy
news.content:
Conrad Mupesa

Mashonaland West Bureau

ZIMBABWEs largest water body, Lake Kariba, has the potential to contribute significantly to the countrys aquaculture sector, a senior Government official has said.

Director of the Fisheries and Aquaculture Resources Department in the Ministry of Lands, Agriculture, Fisheries, Water and Rural Development, Mr Milton Makumbe said this at the two-day Fisheries and Aquaculture Bill stakeholders consultation meeting in Kariba yesterday.

He said Kariba has the potential to contribute towards the growth of the countrys economy.

Lake Kariba has the potential to significantly contribute to food security, economic growth and improved nutrition, he said.

He, however, said limited investment have hindered the full realisation of this potential.

Mr Makumbe said the enactment of the Bill will establish an enabling environment for the sustainable usage of the lake and ensure that aquaculture contributes significantly to the countrys blue economy.

Lake Kariba is the largest water body in Zimbabwe, hosting the countrys biggest aquaculture farm, Lake Harvest.
news.description: ZIMBABWE's largest water body, Lake Kariba, has the potential to contribute significantly to the country's aquaculture sector, a senior Government official has said.

news.title: Fidel Castro our hero: Minister Tawengwa
news.content:
Blessings Chidakwa

Herald Reporter

President of the Cuban National Assembly, Honourable Esteban Lazo Hernandez has laid a wreath at Fidel Castro Square which is along the road bearing the same name.

Speaking at the event, Minister of State Harare Metropolitan Provincial Affairs and Devolution, Senator Charles Tawengwa said the Cuban delegations visit to Zimbabwe is a testament to the close relations that exist between Zimbabwe and Cuba.

Minister Tawengwa said the relations of brotherhood and collaboration were born in the period of Zimbabwes liberation struggle, leading to the attainment of independence in 1980.

We recall with fond memories that, led by the revolutionary Commander-in-Chief, Fidel Castro Ruz, Cuba supported us by training our combatants and providing arms and other materials for that struggle, he said.

Speaking of revolutionaries, we took it upon ourselves to imprint those heroes who helped us achieve our liberation cause.

Therefore, the Government of Zimbabwe in 2020 renamed this road, formerly Charter Road, as Fidel Castro Road.

This is a gesture that we believe will remind future generations of the solid bond between Zimbabwe and Cuba.

The Cuban delegation has since met President Mnangagwa at State House.
news.description: President of the Cuban National Assembly, Honourable Esteban Lazo Hernandez has laid a wreath at Fidel Castro Square which is along the road bearing the same name.

news.title: China discovers ‘limitless’ energy source
news.content:
China has reportedly discovered a limitless energy source that could power the country for more than 60 000 years, according to geologists based in Beijing.

The Bayan Obo mining complex, located in Inner Mongolia, is believed to contain enough thorium to meet Chinas energy demands almost indefinitely, according to a recent study.

The slightly radioactive element can be used to generate power in a type of nuclear reactor known as a molten salt reactor.

Scientists estimate that the mining complex could provide as much as one million tons of thorium, The South China Morning Post reported, citing a newly declassified study.

The study argues that Chinas thorium reserves, currently locked within mining waste, remain totally untouched and that, if properly extracted, they could be substantial enough to end the worlds reliance on fossil fuels.  The Daily Mail / Picture:  Pixabay)
news.description: China has reportedly discovered a ‘limitless’ energy source that could power the country for more than 60 000 years, according to geologists based in Beijing.

news.title: Zim-Cuba to upscale relations
news.content:
Zvamaida Murwira

Senior Reporter

Zimbabwe and Cuba should boost economic ties that benefit the two sister countries, president of the Cuban National Assembly, Honourable Esteban Lazo Hernandez has said.

Honourable Hernandez said this after holding bilateral talks with President Mnangagwa at State House today.

He said there is need for the two countries to solidify their long-standing relations, which date to the liberation struggle.

We are convinced that we must take our economic relations to the same level as that of our political ties, he said. We have agreed on issues that will mutually benefit our two sister countries.
news.description: Zimbabwe and Cuba should boost economic ties that benefit the two sister countries, president of the Cuban National Assembly, Honourable Esteban Lazo Hernandez has said.

news.title: Access to inputs hinders Zimbabwe’s aquaculture growth
news.content:
Theseus Shambare in KARIBA

Access to crucial inputs has become a major obstacle for Zimbabwes aquaculture sector, limiting its growth potential.

This issue was highlighted during the final consultations for the Fisheries and Aquaculture Bill in Kariba.

An aquaculture expert under the Fisheries and Aquaculture Resources Department (FARD), Mrs Irene Chihanga said while aquaculture production has become a vital component of global food production, the rising costs of production continues to plague the sector.

A recent survey we conducted revealed that access to essential inputs is a major hurdle for Zimbabwes aquaculture sector, said Mrs Chihanga.

For an aquaculture enterprise to be productive, it is necessary to ensure that quality and cost-effective inputs are available. Inputs such as feed, fingerlings, chemicals, drugs and quality water are crucial for the sustainability and profitability of aquaculture operations.

The survey, she said, found that commercial feed is the most commonly used, particularly in the Midlands and Matabeleland South provinces.

However, farmers also rely on alternative sources, Chihanga noted.

Specifically, they exploit kitchen waste (85,71 percent in Matabeleland North and 60 percent in Matabeleland South) and livestock manure (33,33 percent for pig and poultry).

A significant factor contributing to this is the distance that farmers must travel to access feed, with those in the Midlands and Matabeleland North Provinces traveling the furthest.

Generally, farmers in the Midlands province travel 156km, while those in Matabeleland North travel 126km to access fish feed, she said.

The survey also revealed price disparities in feed and fingerlings across provinces.

The cost of fish feed per kilogram is higher in Masvingo Province compared to others, while it is comparatively lower in Matabeleland North and Manicaland, she said.

The lower fingerling prices in Manicaland could be attributed to the use of recycled fish seed, while in Matabeleland North, it is due to reliance on wild fish seed.

Farmers attending the Bill consultations chipped in.

On top of limited-service providers, there is a rise in bogus suppliers of pond liners, said Takunda Chikumbindi, a young fish farmer from Chinhoyi.

I had the problem of receiving poor-quality plastic, which I had to replace twice within a single seven-month cycle.

Agnes Samukange from Dzikamidzi, Zvimba District, added, Feed scarcity is weighing down my project. We incur extra costs every time we need fish feed because we dont have suppliers in our area. We end up using substandard feeds like kitchen waste, which dont produce the intended quality fish.

In response, FARD, in collaboration with the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) under the Fish for Africa, Caribbean, and Pacific (FISH4ACP) programme, has begun decentralising aquaculture inputs to bring them closer to farmers.

Recently, fingerling distribution hubs were launched in Masvingo and Manicaland to reduce transportation costs for farmers.

Well-managed fisheries can ensure a sustainable supply of healthy aquatic foods. However, fishery resources are limited, and the increasing global demand for aquatic foods require a well-managed aquaculture sector to fill the gap, said Mr Paul Mwera, FAO FISH4ACP programme coordinator.

FISH4ACP has supported the Government in developing fingerling distribution hubs to address the challenge of accessing fingerlings.

FARD director, Mr Milton Makumbe emphasised the importance of collaborations with development partners.

The challenges in the fish value chain are numerous and some directly affect the efficiency and growth of the subsector, he said.

These include but are not limited to the absence of an enabling legal framework, poor seed quality, limited financial capital, poor production technologies, poor marketing, slow uptake and adoption of sustainable community-based aquaculture initiatives, and climate change-induced water shortages. The development of this Bill is a significant step towards our vision.
news.description: Access to crucial inputs has become a major obstacle for Zimbabwe’s aquaculture sector, limiting its growth potential.

news.title: Education Minister vows to weed out corrupt elements
news.content:
Trust Freddy

Herald Correspondent

The Government will not tolerate any form of corruption, chicanery, nepotism, or favouritism that undermines the integrity of the countrys education system, Primary and Secondary Education Minister Torerai Moyo has said.

Speaking during a meeting with senior ministry officials in Harare today, Minister Moyo vowed to deal decisively with all unscrupulous officials.

This comes amid revelations that some senior officials, particularly in the Ministrys Human Resources Department, are reportedly demanding bribes of up to US$300 to facilitate transfers, rebate letters, and other services.

In our pursuit of excellence, we must adopt a zero-tolerance policy towards corruption, particularly in the Human Resources Department, concerning employment, transfers, rebate letters and other related matters, Minister Moyo said.

Integrity in these processes is non-negotiable. We must hold ourselves accountable to the highest standards, and we must eradicate any practices that allow corruption to thrive. We must act decisively to uphold our standards and restore trust in the system.

news.title: Highfield’s Mbizi Police Post turned into liberation heritage site
news.content:
Senior Reporter

The Zimbabwe Republic Police, in partnership with Southerton Constituency Community Development Trust (SCCDT), have rehabilitated Mbizi Police Post in Highfield, which has been turned into a liberation heritage site.

The police post is where most nationalists who were residing in and around Highfield were detained during the liberation struggle.

SCCDT recently wrote a letter to the ZRP requesting an approval for renovations at the police post to the tune of US$10 000. They also requested that the police post be turned into a heritage site.

The request was then forwarded to the Ministry of Home Affairs and Cultural Heritage, which approved it.

A letter written by SDCCT chairman, Cde Andrew Makahamadze read: Mbizi Police Station is of paramount importance since it is endowed with a rich history. Liberation stalwarts and founding fathers of Zimbabwe, like the late former President Robert

Mugabe, were once incarcerated there. We feel honoured to be part of heritage protectors

In his acceptance speech, acting Officer Commanding Harare Province, Commissioner Tawonei Nyazema said: Your support to the province and the ZRP is of great significance. We appreciate the cordial relationship that we enjoy.

news.title: Company loses US$120k to robbers
news.content:
Crime Reporter

Five robbers last week stole over US$120 000 from a Harare company after attacking the security guard.

The money was in one of the offices on the premises in Workington.

National police spokesperson, Commissioner Paul Nyathi confirmed the incident.

Police in Harare are investigating a case of robbery that occurred on February 27, 2025, at a company in Workington, he said.

Five unknown suspects attacked a security guard who was on duty and gained entry into the offices where they stole US$120 400. Anyone with information can report at the nearest police station.
news.description: Five robbers last week stole over US$120 000 from a Harare company after attacking the security guard.

news.title: Empowering youths a catalyst for Africa’s prosperity
news.content:
Remember Deketeke

Herald Reporter

Youths have been urged to shun dependency and embrace innovation, which positions them to be the key drivers of Africas economic growth.

These remarks were made last Friday at the Youth Leadership Diplomatic Conference in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

The event was convened under the theme A Pact for the New Spirit of Pan-Africanism through Globalisation, Innovation-Led Economic Integration, and Peacebuilding.

Ethiopias Minister of Women and Social Affairs, Dr Ergoge Tesfaye emphasised the pivotal role of young leaders in achieving Africas economic and political aspirations.

Young leaders hold the key to unlocking Africas potential. Their vision and innovation are essential in driving the continent towards sustainable economic growth and political empowerment, she said.

Empowering the youth is not just an investment in individuals, but a commitment to a future where Africa stands tall, self-reliant, and ready to take the lead on the global stage.

International Youth Connect (IYC) spokesperson Mr Daniel Zinyama echoed the same sentiments, underscoring the need for peace as a foundation for economic growth and sustainable development.

Peace is the bedrock of prosperity. Wthout it, economic growth is merely a fleeting dream, overshadowed by conflict and instability, he said.

Sustainable development flourishes in a climate of peace, where communities can unite, innovate, and invest in their futures without the threat of disruption.

He added that Governments must invest in digital skills training programmes to prepare youths for the evolving job market.

During the conference, a call to strengthen regional institutions like ECOWAS, SADC, and the AU was made as they are vital for fostering unity, enhancing collaboration, and addressing shared challenges, ultimately paving the way for a more integrated and resilient Africa.
